p.seg: 《FOREST OF LAUGHTER》 (5TH CENT. AD) 1. A southerner from Wu came to the capital in the north
and was given a meal of yoghurt paste.
He did not know what the substance was
but forced himself to eat it.
On his way home he vomited and felt desperately sick.
He told his son:
"If I had died together with these bastards
I would surely have nothing to regret.
But you, then, must beware of this!"
2. A fire broke out one night in the home of a man from Taiyuan.
He was removing his possessions from the house.
Intending to carry out a copper kettle,
by mistake he caught hold of a pressing iron instead.
He was greatly amazed
and he said to his son:
"This is amazing!
"The fire hasn't even got to the tripod,
and already the legs have got burnt off!"
3. One night a certain Mr. X felt terribly sick
and told his servant to light a lamp.
The night was quite dark and the servant could not find the lighter.
"Get on with it, will you!", urged Mr. X.
His servant got angry and said:
"You are not being fair!
It is pitch dark now. Why don't you shine a torch for me?
Then I'll quickly find what I need to light the lamp. When Kong Wenju heard this one he said:
"When anyone criticises others one should use this method."
4. Someone was about to pay a condolence visit and wanted to contribute a gift.
He asked: "What kind of thing should one give?"
The other person replied: "Cash, cloth, grain silk, whatever you have, my friend."
And so our condoler handed over a bushel of beans to the mourner, saying:
"I have nothing, and so I hand over a bushel of horse beans in your support."
The mourner shouted: "What am I to do (without the beloved person who has just died)?"
Our man thought by himself that the mourner was asking about the beans.
and he said: "You can prepare a meal with them!"
The mourner again wailed: "I have nowhere to turn!"
and our man said:
"Since you happen to be so poor, I should present me with one more bushel!"
5. Shen Heng of Wu had a younger brother Jun with the given name Shushan
He was a man of great fame,
but by nature Jun was tight-fisted and penny-pinching.
Now, when Zhang Wen went on a mission to Shu and paid Jun a farewell visit,
Jun spent a long time with him.
As he was about to leave, Jun told Zhang Wen:
"Just now I was going to pick out some cloth that I meant to present to you.
However, there was none of the rough (and cheap) variety left..."
Zhang Wen showed himself impressed by Jun's willingness to disclose openly his own faults.
6. Zhao Bogong was a fat man.
One summer day he was taking a nap after a bout of drinking
when his grandson, a few years old, climbed up on his stomach.
Just for the fun of it, the boy squeezed seven or eight plums into the sleeping man's fleshy fold around the navel.
When he sobered up, Zhao never realised what had happened.
Several days later, Zhao began to feel uncomfortable.
The plums had rotted and their juice was oozing out.
Zhao imagined his stomach was punctured.
He was scared to death. He told his wife to look after the household.
and then, in tears, he told his family:
"My guts are rotting away. I am dying!".
The next day the plum stones poped out of his navel, and he asked what had happened.
Then he realized that his grandson had played him a trick.

7. At the time of emperor Huan (A.D. 147-167) there was an Imperial Secretary who implored somebody else to compose the edicts and to write the reports for him. This person was unable to oblige and said:
"But Ge Long from the state of Liang has been good at this quite some time ago. You can copy his stuff and use it. No need to do the work all over again."
So the Secretary followed this advice. He copied from the writings composed by this Ge Long, signature and all.
The palace officials were appalled. Without even replying officially they summarily dismissed the Secretary and sent him into retirement.
The people of the time had a saying:
"When composing a memorial, no matter how much work you put into it, make sure you leave out the name Ge Long."
8. The Han minister of education Cui Lie had retired to Shàngdǎng
where Bao Jian was the local prefect.
Bao Jian was going to pay the minister a visit.
In order to avoid any faux pas
he asked someone who had visited the minister earlier about the formalities to be observed.
The answer he got was
that he should simply follow the butler in his actions.
When Bao Jian paid his visit he was told: "You may bow!" "You may bow", he echoed.
"Take your seat!", said the butler. "Take your seat!", echoed Bao Jian.
Since he left his shoes on before he took his seat
he could obviously not find his shoes again when he was about to leave.
"The shoes are on your feet!", said the butler.
"The shoes are on your feet!", echoed the visitor.
9. A man from Chu was carrying a live pheasant over his shoulder and was asked by a by-passer: "What bird is this?".
"It's a phoenix bird!", the man lied.
"I have long heard stories about the phoenix bird, and now at last I have seen one.
Are you prepared to sell it?".
"Yes I am"
The passerby offered 1000 cash for the bird, but the man from Chu refused, demanding twice the price. The passerby paid.
The bird's new owner intended to present it to the King of Chu, but the bird died during that night.
The new owner was not upset about his money, but he was deeply upset that he would be unable to present the bird to his king.
Rumours about the bird spread throughout the state. Everybody thought the bird was genuine and valuable, and that it was very fitting to want to present it to the king.
In the end the affair came to the notice of the king himself,
who was profoundly grateful for his subject's desire to present him with the bird.
He summoned its owner and rewarded him most generously:
the reward as ten times as high as he bird's original price.
Tao Qiu from Pingyuan married a girl Motai from Bohai
who was of exceptional beauty and of great talent.
The two had great respect for each other,
but after they had got a son he divorced her and sent her home.
The girl's mother, Ding by name, and quite old, barged in to demand an explanation.
The son-in-law had already sent his wife away. Now he went on to send the old lady away as well.
But before leaving, the old lady asked what wrong her daughter had done.
"Some time ago when I met you", explained the son-in-law,
"as the years had gone by, your beauty had declined
and was not what it used to be.
I got afraid that my wife, in due course, would surely also turn out like that.
Therefore I sent her away.
There was no other reason!"
10. A certain Mr. X, a local administrative assistant, was by nature an ignorant man.
At social gatherings there would invariably be music, and Mr. X, who attended many such events,
was ashamed that these recitals meant nothing whatever to him.
When people applauded a singing girl's performance he would just blindly join in the applause.
There came a time when the gentlemen around Mr. X demanded that he should take his turn as host and assemble singing girls and guests.
Before the guests and the singing girls had all arrived, he took aside some singing girls
and asked them what they were going to sing. He noted down all the titles and hid his notes under a box for handkerchiefs.
There he had previously put a list of medical prescriptions. When the guests had all arrived they asked what the musical programme was going to be.
Mr. X was quick to look for his notes, but by mistake he caught hold of the medical prescriptions instead:
"Three grammes of poisonous fuzi weed root", he read, "danggui leaves, four grammes, etc. etc."
"For the pleasure of the guests we will have fuzi and danggui", he finally announced.
The assembled guests fell over with laughter.
11. When a southerner went to the capital people warned him:
"You simply must eat whatever is before you. Don't ask what it is, just eat it."
Later on he was visiting someone in a private home, when he caught sight of horse dropping which he promtly ate. The thing stank terribly, and he stopped up.
He then went along on his way and noticed a worn-out straw sandal that had been left by the road.
Again he chewed away at it, but it was hard to get the sandal down his throat.
"Hold it!", said an onlooker. "You mustn't do everything people tell you!"
Some time later the southerner was offered (delicate) steamed meat-balls as he was visiting a high official.
The southerner gave the food a hard look:
"I've never seen this before. My earlier experiences suggest that I better avoid this and do not eat it."
12. Somebody was having hacked vegetable soup and he was trying some of it with a ladle.
There was too little salt, so he added some more.
After that he tasted from the same ladle:
"That was not enough salt", he said to himself.
In this way he added a full sheng-measure of salt, but the soup remained bland.
"Strange!", he thought to himself.
X had bought some meat. On his way home he entered a public lavatory
and hung the meat so it was visible from the outside.
Y stole the meat, but before he got away,
X emerged from the lavatory
to look for his meat.
The thief shrewdly put the meat in his mouth and said:
"If you hang the meat on the outer door, of course you are going to lose it!.
If on the other hand I put it into my mouth, it cannot possibly disappear!"
13. Yao Biao and Zhang Wen were travelling to Wuchang together when near a small Island on the Yangtse river
they met Wu Xing and Shen Xing. Wu Xing and Shen Xing were waiting for a fair wind
and were getting low on supplies, so they sent someone to borrow 100 measures of salt from Yao Biao.
Now Biao was by nature a serious and a straightforward man.
He was just in conversation with Zhang Wen and did not reply to the note of request.
After a long while he ordered his servants
"Pour 100 measures of salt into the river."
Turning to Wēn he said:
"You understand: It's not because of the salt.
It's because of the person asking for it".
14. A poor man from Chu had read the following in the magical book Huainan fang:
"The praying mantis, when catching a cicada, will cover itself with a leaf so that the body is completely hidden."
Some time later he was about to pick a leaf on a tree and found that a praying mantis was hiding under it,
which was clearly waiting to catch a cicada.
He plucked the leaf off the tree but dropped it on the ground under the tree.
Now there were plenty of leaves already under the tree and there was no way of telling which one he had just dropped.
So he took home several dippers full of leaves tried them one by one and asked his wife each time whether she could see him.
At first his wife kept replying "Yes"
but as the days wore on she got fed up with the whole thing and she suddenly said: "NO!".
The man was delighted, took the leaf to the market and proceeded to steal things, quite openly, in front of everybody.
Officials tied him up and charged him in court.
The district court official received the explanations of the accused who gave the whole story from beginning to end.
The attending legal officers broke into laughter and dismissed the case.
15. In Han times there was an old, childless man,
rich and by nature stingy, who wore poor clothing and ate coarse food.
He rose early (to make use of the daylight) and went to bed early in the evening (to save lamp-oil).
In the course of his business dealings he had piled up wealth, but he refused to use any of these riches for himself.
Now a beggar came to this rich man's door,
and the rich man saw nothing for it but to go inside and find ten small pieces of cash.
As he emerged from his room he reduced his largesse by a little for every step he took, and by the time he came out
he had arrived at half the original sum. Closing his eyes he handed the beggar the cash
with this remark:
"I have ruined my home to satisfy your needs. Do not under any circumstances tell others that you have got anything from me,
or they all come here as you did."
The rich old man suddenly died and his lands and home were turned over to the local officials
and his property was added to the coffers of the administration.
A certain X wanted to pay the district magistrate a formal visit. He asked the people around what the magistrate liked.
"The Gongyang commentary!", somebody suggested.
Later X went in to see the mayor and was immediately asked:
"What book do you specialise in?"
"The Gongyang commentary!"
"Who, then, killed Chen Tuo?", asked the mayor after a while (to test his visitor).
"Not me! I never did it!", replied the visitor after some hesitation.
The mayor saw that his visitor was a fraud, so he went on teasing him:
"If you haven't done it, Sir, then who did it?"
X was so terrified that he ran out bare-footed, forgetting to put on his shoes again.
"Why this haste?", he was asked. "I paid a visit in the Yamen and was questioned in connection with a murder."
After that he never dared to show himself again. It was only after there had been an amnesty that he ventured outside once more.
16. X and Y had a quarrel
during whch X bit off Y's nose.
Before the magistrate who was to decide the case,
X claimed that Y had himself bitten off his own nose.
"The nose is higher than the mouth: how can one bite off one's own nose?"
"The fellow stood on a bed-frame as he did it!"
A Mr. X went spent three years studying abroad while his parents were still alive.
A relative asked him what he had got out of his study.
And would he compose a formal farewell essay to his father (to show his skill).
"In my thoughts of Weiyang I surpass Qin Kang", intoned Mr. X (thus indicating his deep respect to the relative he talks to through a learned allusion to the ancient Book of Songs.)
"What's the use of your studies?", the father chided him.
"As a child I did not get a proper education. Thereafter study is of no use."
17. Three vulgar fellows wanted to pay a visit of condolence, but none of them knew the ritual rules for this.
However, one of these people thought he had a rough idea of what was required,
and he told his cronies to do exactly as he did.
When they came to the place of mourning
the one who had some practice from before bowed on the mat before the tablet of the deceased.
The others followed suit one after the other and with their heads which have been shaved bare as a punishment for some offence they knocked each other's backs.
"You idiots!", said the leader and kicked the man behind him with his foot.
"You idiots!", the next one repeated faithfully,
as he dutifully kicked third fellow.
"You idiots!", repeated the third man to one of the other mourners and kicked him as well.
18. There was a foolish bridegroom whose father-in-law had died,
and whose wife had told him to behave at the funeral.
On his way to the funeral ceremony he came to a river,
took off his socks, waded across,
and left one sock behind.
Then as he passed through a forest he heard a pidgeon crying "Bu-ku, Bu-ku".
As he was imitating this sound to himself he forgot all about the funeral.
When at last he arrived at the place of mourning,
he stood on the one foot that had a sock on and drew the bare foot up,
just muttering: "Bu-ku, Bu-ku".
The mourners all laughed.
"Why don't you stop laughing
and return my sock if you find it!", said the foolish bridegroom.
19. In Lu there was a man who wanted to enter a city gate with a long pole.
First he carried the pole upright,
but it would not go through the gate.
Then he tried carrying it sideways,
but it was still impossible to get it in.
He was stuck.
"It isn't as if I was a sage or anything"
"but I have seen a thing or two in my life.
Now, why don't you saw this pole in two. You'll get it in that way."
The man from Lu did as he was told and broke the pole.
20. A man from Qi, having learnt the lute from a man of Zhao,
tuned the instrument and then glued the pegs in place.
For three years he did not manage to play a single decent tune.
"Strange!", thought the man of Qi.
When somebody from Zhao came along,
our man of Qi asked his expert opinion. The visitor from Zhao soon understood the stupidity that had caused the problem.
Hu Yong from the state of Wu
was romantically inclined.
He married a woman by the name of Zhang
whom he loved so much that he never allowed her to leave him.
In the end the woman died,
and soon Hu Yong died too.
Their family buried them provisionally in the back garden.
Three years later, when the time came for the proper funeral
it turned out that the funeral mounds had taken the form of two people.
They often looked as if they slept together embracing each other.
This always made people smile.
21. A Han man went to Wu in the south,
and the natives offered him bamboo shoots to eat.
"What is this?", he asked.
"Bamboo", was the reply.
Upon his return home the Han man boiled the bamboo poles of his bedding, but they wouldn't get done.
"Real bastards, these people from Wu,
fooling me like this!" he complained to his wife.
